pages.text: Fundamental to the core mechanics of QMD are subatomic particles. In QMD you create, manipulate, transmute, and annihilate particles.

pages.title: Particle stacks
pages.text: In QMD, particles are stored in particle stacks, like items in minecraft are stored in item stacks. But, there are major differences between particle stacks and item stacks. Particle Stacks cannot be held by the player, as they are not items, but generally beams of particles. Particle stacks have 4 properties: $(li)Type $(li)Energy $(li)Focus $(li)Amount

pages.title: Type
pages.text: Particles come in many different types. Some examples are protons, neutrons, and electrons, which make up all the atoms around you. Each of them have different properties like mass, charge, and spin, and they can be used for different things. Their properties can be seen on JEI particle information tab.

pages.title: Energy
pages.text: Each particle stack has an associated kinetic energy, measured in electron volts (eV), quantifying how fast the particle is moving. The energy is the most important property of a particle stack, as it can determine what reactions (recipes) they can be used for.

The energy of particles are manipulated using accelerators. $(l:accelerators/linear_accelerator)Linear$(/l) and $(l:accelerators/ring_accelerator)Synchrotron$(/l) accelerators increase their energy, while $(l:accelerators/decelerators)Decelerators$(/l) decrease their energy. The energy of particles can also be changed in reactions.

pages.title: Focus
pages.text: Focus is how confined a beam of particles is. Focus's main purpose is to tell you how far the beam of particles can travel. $(bold)If a particle stack focus is less than or equal to zero, it cannot propagate$(). Each block the particles travel, they lose focus equivalent to the beam attenuation rate, seen on the tool tips for te $(item)Beam Blocks$() and $(item)Beamlines$().

Focus is also used in some reactions, as some reactions have a minimum focus or focus range, which are stated on the recipes (specifically, if you hover over the input particle to a recipe in JEI, it's focus will be the minimum required).

pages.title: Amount
pages.text: The amount of particles within a stack is measured in particle units (pu). Generally, it represents the particle units per tick. For example, a $(item)Tungsten Filament$() gives off 100 pu of electrons, meaning it gives off 100 pu/t.

in some reactions in the $(l:particle_chambers/target_chamber)Target Chamber$(/l), $(l:particle_chambers/beam_dump)Beam Dump$(/l) or $(l:containment_chambers/neutral_containment)Neutral Containment Chamber$(/l), it is the cumulative amount needed to complete the recipe. For example, a recipe that requires 120 kpu will take 1200 ticks to complete with a 100 pu/t source.
